Jesse_Lee_(singer):
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Other uses|Jesse Lee (disambiguation){{!}}Jesse Lee}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Jesse Lee | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Jessica Lee Levin | birth_place = | birth_date = {{circa}} {{birth year and age|1986}}{{cite web |url= http://www.theboot.com/2009/05/04/new-faces-jesse-lee/ |title= New Faces: Jesse Lee |last= Mullin |first= Simon |date= 2009-05-04 |work= The Boot |accessdate= 2009-05-26 |archive-date= 2012-02-27 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120227043643/http://www.theboot.com/2009/05/04/new-faces-jesse-lee/ |url-status= live }} | origin = [[Palo Alto, California]], United States | instrument = [[Singing|Vocals]] | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[Songwriter]] | years_active = 2003-present | label = Direct Image
[[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]/Bigger Picture (Former) | associated_acts = [[Rachel Proctor]], [[Victoria Banks]], [[Uncle Kracker]] | website = }} '''Jesse Lee''' (born {{circa}} 1986) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. Signed to [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic Nashville]] in 2007, she released her debut single "It's a Girl Thing" in 2009, which debuted on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart dated for June 6, 2009. A second single, "[[Like My Mother Does]]," was released in 2010, which failed to chart. Jesse and Atlantic Records parted ways after three and a half years together. She is signed as a songwriter with [[Disney Music Group]].{{cite web |title=Jesse Lee Signs With Disney Music Group |url=https://musicrow.com/2018/10/jesse-lee-signs-with-disney-music-group/ |website=Music Row |date=30 October 2018 |accessdate=7 November 2018 |archive-date=8 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181108025822/https://musicrow.com/2018/10/jesse-lee-signs-with-disney-music-group/ |url-status=live }} In addition to her solo career, Lee co-wrote [[Kelsea Ballerini]]'s "[[Peter Pan (Kelsea Ballerini song)|Peter Pan]]".{{Cite news |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2016/12/23/how-kelsea-ballerinis-peter-pan-took-flight/95630824/ |last1=Paulson |first1=Dave |date=December 23, 2016 |title=How Kelsea Ballerini's 'Peter Pan' took flight |website=The Tennessean |access-date=February 7, 2023 }} ==Biography== Jesse Lee was raised in [[Los Altos, California]].{{cite web|title=Jesse Lee biography |url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_5942770,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130124090913/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_5942770,00.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2013-01-24 |work=[[Great American Country]] |access-date=2009-05-26 }} Inspired by country music at an early age, she began performing in state festivals by age eleven before her family moved to [[Florida]], eventually serving as an opening act for [[Ronnie Milsap]], [[Willie Nelson]] and [[Clay Walker]]. By age 14, she had made her first trip to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] to collaborate with hit songwriters, as well as record [[demo (music)|demo]]s. She attended [[Belmont University]]'s music business program after graduating from high school, meanwhile performing at local songwriters' clubs. She co-wrote and sang the duet "Me Again" on [[Uncle Kracker]]'s album ''[[Happy Hour (Uncle Kracker album)|Happy Hour]]'' and wrote the title track to [[Kristy Lee Cook]]'s debut album ''[[Why Wait (album)|Why Wait]]''. Jesse was living in Nashville at the time but traveled back to [[Jacksonville, Florida]], where Lee was singing at a fair and was discovered by someone who sent her music to the president of [[Atlantic Records]], who upon hearing her demo, flew her to New York and offered her a record deal.{{cite web | title=Jesse Lee biography | url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/lee__jesse/bio.jhtml | work=CMT | access-date=2009-05-26 | archive-date=2009-04-18 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418193424/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/lee__jesse/bio.jhtml | url-status=dead }} Her debut album is produced by [[Paul Worley]], Mark Bright and [[Nathan Chapman (record producer)|Nathan Chapman]], and it includes her debut single "It's a Girl Thing", which debuted at No. 59 on the U.S. country charts dated for June 6, 2009. The song was also made into a [[music video]], which has aired on [[Country Music Television|CMT]].{{cite web | title="It's a Girl Thing" video | url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/jesse-lee/369549/its-a-girl-thing.jhtml | work=CMT | access-date=2009-05-26 | archive-date=2009-06-21 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090621191503/http://www.cmt.com/videos/jesse-lee/369549/its-a-girl-thing.jhtml | url-status=dead }} "It's a Girl Thing" received a favorable review from Matt Bjorke of Roughstock, who said that the song (which she co-wrote with [[Victoria Banks]] and [[Rachel Proctor]]) had a mainstream sound but showcased Lee's vocals.{{cite web|url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/jesse-lee-it-s-a-girl-thing- |title=Jesse Lee — "It's a Girl Thing" |last=Bjorke |first=Matt |date=2009-04-20 |work=Roughstock |access-date=2009-05-26 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090506060358/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/jesse-lee-it-s-a-girl-thing- |archive-date=2009-05-06 }} Karlie Justus of Engine 145 gave it a thumbs-down rating, saying that the song was cliché and stereotyped, although she also described Lee's vocal performance favorably.{{cite web|url=http://www.engine145.com/jesse-lee-its-a-girl-thing/ |title=Jesse Lee — "It's a Girl Thing" |last=Justus |first=Karlie |date=2009-05-14 |work=Engine 145 |access-date=2009-05-26 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218104823/http://www.engine145.com/jesse-lee-its-a-girl-thing/ |archive-date=2014-12-18 }} In 2016, Lee celebrated her first #1 song, [[Kelsea Ballerini]]'s "[[Peter Pan (Kelsea Ballerini song)|Peter Pan]]". In 2016, Jesse penned one of the 13 songs on Keith Urban's album RIPCORD, "That Could Still Be Us". In January 2018, Jesse Lee had her second consecutive #1 song with Brett Young, "Like I Loved You." It was a 3-week Billboard number one which she co-wrote with Brett Young. In 2022, [[Dean Brody]] recorded "[[You Got the Wrong Guy]]", which was co-written by Lee.{{cite web|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2022/10/04/dean-brody-shares-his-new-single-you-got-the-wrong-guy/|title=Dean Brody shares his new single, "You Got The Wrong Guy"|date=October 4, 2022|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|work=Canadian Beats Media|access-date=February 28, 2023}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== *''Hotel'' (2015) ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2"| Single ! colspan="1"| Peak positions ! rowspan="2"| Album |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="50"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]] |- | 2003 | align="left"| "Room to Breathe" | — | align="left"| ''Room to Breathe'' |- | 2009 | align="left"| "It's a Girl Thing"{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/jesse-lee/chart-history/country-songs/song/608404|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180508104304/https://www.billboard.com/music/jesse-lee/chart-history/country-songs/song/608404|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 8, 2018|title="It's a Girl Thing" chart history|magazine=Billboard|accessdate=3 January 2018}} | 52 | rowspan=2 align="left"| Non-album song |- | 2010 | align="left"| "[[Like My Mother Does]]" | — |- | colspan="4" style="font-size:8pt"| "—" denotes releases that did not chart |- |} ===Music videos=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Year ! Video ! Director |- | 2009 | "It's a Girl Thing" | Mark Staubach |- |} ===Other appearances=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Song !
